erm_det_type.description: A radiation counting instrument used in laboratory measurements.

DET_ID.description: The unique abbreviation for a detector.

DET_NUM.description: The number of the detector used for the analysis.

DET_TYPE_ID.description: The abbreviation for the type of detector. The valid values and descriptions are: AA = Atomic Absorption Spectrometer AIR = Air Filter Beta Counter AS = Alpha Spectrometer FIMS = Flow Injection Mercury System GELI = Lithium-drifted Germanium Gamma Detector HPGE = High-Purity Germanium Gamma Detector IPC = Internal Proportional Alpha Counter ICPMS = ICP/MS LBAB = Low-Background Alpha-Beta Counter LBB = Low-Background Beta Counter LS = Liquid Scintillation Counter NAI = Sodium Iodide Gamma Detector SC = Scintillation Counter UNK =  Unknown type

erm_ana_proc.description: The name of the analytical procedure that was used on the sample. The specific procedure depends on several factors, including the medium and the radionuclide or radiation type of interest.

ANA_PROC_ID.description: The official EPA or National Air and Radiation Environmental Laboratory (NAREL) analytical procedure identifier.

ANA_PROC_NAME.description: The name of the analytical procedure that was used on the sample. The specific procedure depends on several factors, including the medium and the radionuclide or radiation type of interest.

ANA_PROC_NUM.description: The unique number that identifies an analytical procedure.

PROC_TYPE_ID.description: The abbreviated type of analytical procedure that may correspond to more than one procedure.

erm_analyte.description: The full, descriptive name of an analyte, either a non-specific type of radiation (e.g., gross alpha), or a specific radionuclide (e.g., uranium238).

ANALYTE_ID.description: The name or brief representation of an analyte.

ANALYTE_NAME.description: The full, descriptive name of an analyte, either a non-specific type of radiation (e.g., gross alpha), or a specific radionuclide (e.g., uranium238).

ANA_TYPE.description: The type of analyte where 'R' = radionuclide, 'E' = element, and 'Y' = yield.

HALF_LIFE.description: The quantity part of an element's half-life.

HALF_LIFE_TIME_UNIT.description: The time unit part of an element's half-life.

erm_study.description: The source of a project or a group of closely related projects.

STUDY_ID.description: The unique abbreviation for a study.  Valid values are: PMN = Pasteurized Milk Network RAN =  Radiation Alert Network TR = Precipitation Network DW = Drinking Water Newtwork SW = Surface Water Network

STUDY_NAME.description: The name or description of the study.

STUDY_NUM.description: The unique number for a study.

erm_project.description: A monitoring activity that has a definite beginning and end.  Usually there is a different project for each quarter of the study.

STUDY_NUM.description: The unique number for a study.

erm_location.description: The name of the city in or near where the sample was taken, and the name of the State where the sample was taken. For surface water samples, the name of the surface water body also is provided.

CITY_NAME.description: The name of the city, county, or EPA Region associated with the sampling location.

LOC_NUM.description: The unique number assigned to each sampling location.

STATE_ABBR.description: Metadata no available for this column

STATION.description: The name of the station associated with the sampling location.

SURFACE_WATER_SOURCE.description: The name of the surface water sampling location.

erm_matrix.description: The unique name for a matrix.  Media samples are air, precipitation, drinking water, surface water, or pasturized milk.

MAT_DESC.description: The unique name for a matrix.  Media samples are air, precipitation, drinking water, surface water, or pasturized milk.

MAT_ID.description: The unique name for a matrix.

MAT_NUM.description: The unique number for a matrix.

erm_sample.description: The physical sample collected in the field, or formed by compositing other samples.

CLIENT_ID.description: The client or field sample ID.

COLLECT_END.description: For most media the sampling date is the date the sample was collected.  However, since air samples are taken over a period of time, the end of collection date is used to represent sampling date. For Strontium-90 in milk during the period 1960 through July 1978, sample specific collection dates were not published for routine samples, so the 15th of the month is used as the sampling date for data reporting purposes.  For non-routine samples collected during 1976 and 1977 (i.e., increased samplingdue to Chinese atmospheric nuclear weapons tests) specific collection dates are available and are used.

COLLECT_START.description: The date that the sampling started.  For Strontium-90 in milk during the period 1960 through July 1978, sample specific collection dates were not published for routine samples.  For data presentation purposes, the individual or the composite sample for that month is assumed to be "collected" on the 15th of the month.  For non-routine samples collected during 1976 and 1977 (i.e., increased sampling due to Chinese atmospheric nuclear weapons tests) specific collection dates are available and are used.

LOC_NUM.description: The unique number assigned to each sampling location.

MAT_ID.description: The unique name for a matrix.

SAMP_DESC.description: The specific description of the sample matrix.

SAMP_ID.description: The system-generated number of the sample analyzed.

SAMP_NUM.description: The unique number for the sample that is analyzed.

SAMP_UNIT.description: The unit of measure for the sample size.

erm_count.description: Data describing one counting measurement using one detector.

ANA_NUM.description: The system-generated number for each analysis.

DET_NUM.description: The number of the detector used for the analysis.

DURATION.description: The duration of the count in minutes.

RUN_NUM.description: The number for the count of a repeated analysis.

RUN_START.description: The date and time at the start of the count.

erm_analysis.description: An analysis is the measurement of one or more substances by a well-defined procedure. An analysis may produce one or more results.

ANA_NUM.description: The system-generated number for each analysis.

ANA_PROC_NUM.description: The unique number that identifies an analytical procedure.

ANA_SIZE.description: The amount of the sample taken for analysis.

ANA_SIZE_2.description: The amount of the sample after dilution, digestion, and evaporation.

ANA_UNIT.description: The measurement unit for the analysis size.

ANA_UNIT_2.description: The measurement unit for the amount of the sample after dilution, digestion, and evaporation.

SAMP_NUM.description: The unique number for the sample that is analyzed.

erm_result.description: The amount, activity, or concentration measured.  Amounts can be zero, non-detect (ND), positive or negative. A negative result occurs when random effects and limitations in themeasurement process cause the measured value for the sample to be less than that of the laboratory blank or background, which is subtracted from the sample measurement. Although negative radioactivity is physically impossible, the inclusion of negative results allows better statistical analysis of the data.

ANALYTE_ID.description: The name or brief representation of an analyte.

ANA_NUM.description: The system-generated number for each analysis.

CSU.description: The Combined Standard Uncertainty (CSU) is the estimated standard deviation of the result. The CSU can be used to estimate the "confidence interval" around the amount. Thus, if y is the "best estimate" of  measured radioactivity,  the 95% confidence interval around y ranges from about y-(2xCSU) to y+(2xCSU).  For Strontium-90 in milk during the period of 1960 through July 1978, the uncertainties were +/- 2 pCi/L (two sigma) for Sr-90 concentrations less than 20 pCi/L, and 10% of the concentration for Sr-90 concentrations greater than 20 pCi/L. Sample specific uncertainties are available for data beginning in October 1975 (two sigma).

MDC.description: The ability of the analytical process to detect the analyte for a given sample. It is defined as the minimum concentration that gives a 95% probability of detection when the detection criteria are chosen to give only a 5% probability of false detection in a blank sample.   For Strontium-90 in milk during the period of 1960 through July 1978, the minimum detectable concentrations were reported as either 1 or 2 pCi/L.

RESULT_AMOUNT.description: The amount, activity, or concentration measured.  Amounts can be zero, non-detect (ND), positive or negative. A negative result occurs when random effects and limitations in themeasurement process cause the measured value for the sample to be less than that of the laboratory blank or background, which is subtracted from the sample measurement. Although negative radioactivity is physically impossible, the inclusion of negative results allows better statistical analysis of the data.

RESULT_ID.description: The number that uniquely identifies each result from one analysis.

RESULT_UNIT.description: The unit of measure for the amount.
